resources.string: TeamEPCC consists of four students currently enrolled in the MSc in High Performance Computing or MSc in HPC with Data Science, at The University of Edinburgh. Our team is directly trained by members of EPCC staff, which our couch is also a member of. Our industry partner, Boston Limited, provides us support and hardware. EPCC has confirmation from the HPC Advisory Council that EPCCâ€™s postgraduate students are eligible to participate in the competition.

We have used a wide variety of software in our system. We have GNU compilers on different versions, Intel Compilers from 2016 to 2018 and PGI 17. The Intel compilers distribution is part of the Intel Parallel Studio XE, packing Intel MPI and Intel MKL as well. Since we built a GPU-enabled cluster, we also have multiple versions of CUDA (9.0, 9.1 and 9.2) installed. All running on CentOS 7.5.

string.name: info_gpu
string.div: Our cluster consists of two nodes, each one packing 6 NVIDIA Tesla V100s with 32GB HBM2 memory (12 total). Tesla V100 have a Single-Precision performance of 15.7 Tflops (7.8 for Double-Precision). They have ECC (Error Correction) but we have disabled it in an attempt to gain a little bit more performance. This new version of the Tesla family also has Tensor Cores, specialised for AI related applications, that can run up to 125Tflops.

resources.string: We are using Mellanox Infiniband technology to connect the two nodes. Each node has a Single-Port Mellanox ConnectX-3 MT27500 card capable of up to 56Gb/sec connections. This link will only be used by the applications since we also have a 10 Gigabit Ethernet bridge just for management.

For persistent storage we are using Intel NVMe\'s. Each node has a 1TB PCIe Intel P4500 capable of up to 3200 MB/s for sequential read and 1800 MB/s for sequential write. Each node also have a 250GB SSD for the boot partition, leaving us the full 1TB drive for applications and benchmarking.
Each node has 128GB of SDRAM divided into 8 Micron DDR4 16GB cards running at 2400 MHz.
